properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near or below freezing temperatures tonight. Hazard: Frost and freeze conditions. Timing: tonight, and likely again Monday night and Tuesday night. Impact: Frost sensitive crops and plants could be damaged or killed by frost. Action: Take preventive measures to protect frost sensitive crops and plants. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T17:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T02:16:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3733595266.2020

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: up to 10 cm for some areas. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h, Location: northern and western Nova Scotia. Time span: tonight into Sunday. Remarks: Periods of snow and strong winds are expected to develop this evening over western Nova Scotia where westerly winds blow onshore. These conditions are forecast to spread eastward across northern Nova Scotia later tonight, reaching the Cape Breton Highlands during the overnight hours. Conditions will improve Sunday morning over western areas of the province, and later in the morning or in the afternoon over eastern regions. Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea levels are expected. Locations: the Nova Scotia coastline of the Bay of Fundy and western Cape Breton. Time Span: near high tide tonight for the Bay of Fundy and Sunday morning for western Cape Breton.. Remarks: An intensifying low pressure system will give storm surge combined with large waves. The combined effects may cause minor flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T13:59:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T01:23:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2203804957.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected today over some areas of the Nunavik. Conditions will gradually improve this evening over the communities of Umiujaq, Inukjuak, Puvirnituq and Salluit. However, blizzard conditions will persist Monday over Kuujjuarapik, Sanikiluaq and Kangiqsujuaq. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-11T05:07:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T13:08:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1400296484.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total snowfall: 5-15 cm. Location: Northwestern and south-central New Brunswick. Time span: tonight. Remarks: A mix of snow and rain will continue tonight. The greatest snowfall accumulations will likely be over northern and central regions where snowfall warnings are in effect. The snow will taper off by Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A coastal low pressure system from New England is currently over the Gaspé peninsula. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected tonight. However, there will be great variation in the amounts of snow on ground due to temperatures near the freezing mark along the St. Lawrence River. The combination of strong winds and heavy snow could cause damage to structures and trees. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow expected today. Strong northerly winds will continue across the region. These winds, combined with freshly falling snow, may give visibilities near zero at times today. Gusts of up to 70 km/h are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Potential breaking sea conditions and overwash warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on May 10, 2020. An intense low pressure system approaching from New England will give strong winds on Sunday over the regions specified below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high-amplitude tides could produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast in the vicinity of the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Matane: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallee: 2020-05-10, from 03:00 AM to 06:00 AM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-10T13:59:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T08:53:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2851504781.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly 100 km/h along parts of the coast. Locations: Halifax County - east of Porters Lake to Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County. Time span: until early this morning. Remarks: The highest winds will be confined to exposed areas along the Atlantic Coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A disturbance tracking into northern Quebec is bringing strong northerly winds and blizzard conditions to Naujaat. The strong winds and blizzard conditions are expected to last throughout the day Sunday and should begin to ease late Sunday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A disturbance tracking into northern Quebec is bringing strong northerly winds to the Coral Harbour area. Winds are expected to increase to 70 km/h with gusts around 90 km/h late this morning and will persist into the afternoon. These winds are expected to produce extensive blowing snow with visibilities reduced to 400 metres or less. Conditions should begin to moderate late this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-11T00:19:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T08:20:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2808035450.2020
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will drop near or below the freezing mark overnight tonight. In addition, the unseasonably relatively cool weather will continue for several more days. As a result, the frost advisory for Southwestern Quebec could be maintained for all nights and mornings through the rest of the week, possibly through Wednesday morning. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-11T00:50:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-10T08:51:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2950250125.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The combination of strong northwest winds and snow will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow today. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
